remarks: A category is an abstraction of a structure (a group, a topology, an order...)  Category theory consists in finding new formulation of the concepts associated to those structures (product, substructure...) using morphisms instead of the belonging relation.  That trick has the interesting property that heterogeneous structures like topologies or groups for instance become comparable.  In contrast to definition 3.1 of [Adamek] p. 21, where "A category is a quadruple A = (O, hom, id, o)", a category is defined as an extensible structure consisting of three slots: the objects "O" ( ` ( Base `` c ) ` ), the morphisms "hom" ( ` ( Hom `` c ) ` ) and the composition law "o" ( ` ( comp `` c ) ` ). The identities "id" are defined by their properties related to morphisms and their composition, see condition 3.1(b) in [Adamek] p. 21 and ~ df-cid .  (Note: in category theory morphisms are also called arrows.)  (Contributed by FL, 24-Oct-2007.)  (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 2-Jan-2017.)
